results.title: Early marriage
results.brief_description: Deals with teenage marriage, high school counselling and classroom teaching of marriage preparation. Failures are often due to parents and schools making young marriages difficult, rather than ensuring their success. Discusses types of marriage, religious and civil. Symbolism of the ring and post nuptial ceremonies, which should demonstrate the approval and support of parents and friends.

results.title: Early Learning
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
PGR discusses the question: who is the child’s first educator?, and we talk with parents about their role as educators. The role of kindergartens is examined, and we demonstrate how to encourage a love of learning. We look at the importance of language in the learning process, at various aspects of early speech acquisition, and provide tips on the encouragement of a child to develop language skills. PGR also examines the role books and music can play in a child’s early learning development, and we examine the social aspect of developing learning skills.

results.title: Early interactions (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Victor Lockwood, Michael Philps, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
H.R. Schaffer introduces five experiments which demonstrate the importance of synchronisation between mother and baby. The experiments also show that it is often the baby who initiates the interactions.

results.title: Early handling of spinal injuries
results.creator_credit: Walford Hewitson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
Shows what to do and what not to do in the way of on-the-spot first aid when industrial back injuries occur. Animation illustrates the structure of the spinal column and how paralysis may result from injury to the inner spinal cord. Detailed demonstrations, both in a factory and in a logging camp, show how an accident victim must be handled in order to avoid more serious complications.

results.title: Early frost
results.creator_credit: Gloria Films, Laurent Lavole, Isabelle Pragier and Pierre Pinaud
results.brief_description: An endearing story told through the eyes of 10 year old Caroline. Caroline loves her pet rabbit, Pitou, but her parents are ashamed and concerned to learn that Pitou is attracted to rabbits of the same sex. Their resolution to the ‘perceived’ crisis creates turmoil in their relationship with their daughter as Caroline marks out her own revenge and sets the scene for a wonderfully insightful and intelligent lesson to be learnt for her parents.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gloria Films, Laurent Lavole, Isabelle Pragier and Pierre Pinaud

results.title: Early days yet: a profile of the poet Allen Curnow
results.creator_credit: Shirley Horrocks and Point of View Productions
results.brief_description: This is a beautifully presented documentary about the life and memories of the highly acclaimed New Zealand poet, critic and anthropologist, Allen Curnow. At the age of almost 90, Allen Curnow still wrote poetry using “a ball-point, quantities of A4 paper, and a typewriter”. Charming, gentle and retiring, family man and serious poet, Allen Curnow has won many awards in the world of literature including seven New Zealand Book Awards and the first person outside of Britain to receive the Queen’s Gold Medal for Poetry. The program features Curnow reading several of his poems accompanied by evocative and emotive images to illustrate his writings which often reflect memories of people, places or events from his past. With his quiet sense of humor and reminiscing, and through interviews with his wife Jenny, and fellow poets including Bill Manhire, C.K. Stead, Ian Wedde, Leigh Davis and Elizabeth Smither, Allen Curnow allows us a glimpse into both his personal and his creative life. The documentary takes its title from his latest publication “Early days yet: new and collected poems 1941-1997”. Sadly Allen Curnow passed away on 23 September 2001, three months after completion of this film. Contains archival footage and some scenes in b&w.

results.title: Early days
results.creator_credit: Terence Donovan, London Weekend Television, Consolidated Productions and Anthony Page
results.brief_description: This television adaptation of “Early days”, a play by English playwright David Storey (This sporting life, 1963) which was specifically written for Sir Ralph Richardson and which became an international stage hit playing to audiences in London’s West End, Toronto and Washington, DC., reinforces just how wonderful an actor Richardson is in his superb portrayal of the cantankerous dying Sir Richard Kitchen. Once a powerful politician, Kitchen is living out his last few months in the home of his daughter Mathilda (Sheila Ballentine) and her husband Benson (Gerald Flood). Old age and onset of senility contribute to Kitchen’s rambling and reminiscing and he seems generally determined to be disagreeable with all and sundry, including his granddaughter Gloria (Marty Cruickshank) and her boyfriend, and even Bristol (Edward Judd) who has been employed by Mathilda to look after her father. The dialogue is brilliant, witty and ultimately sadly disturbing. Cast also includes Peter Machin and Michael Bangerter. A theatrical experience for viewers of the small screen.
